relation: When people get hungry or MSR kick us out
People start arriving at MS Research
Functional Grit - small talks that may grow into functional pearls. Open session, anyone can give a quick talk!
Food! Likely we'll head out for a curry
When everyone's finished eating, we'll head for a nearby pub

Brunch, chat and impromptu hacking at The Regal - at least someone will stay on until 1pm, next activity may start earlier though, anyone who may show up late should keep phone numbers for one or more of the contacts
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {7012=7th-8th of August in Cambridge, UK, starting with talks at Microsoft Research and with more planning to happen below., 2817=AngloHaskell 2009 is taking place on the 7th of August at MSR Cambridge, with further activities on the 8th. It's free, and everyone is invited! Simply add your name to the wiki and we'll see you there :-), 16351=Another guest house right next to the station is Tenison Towers (01223 363924)., 13113=Wifi accounts are available on request. The signup deadline's the 31st of July. Everyone wanting an account should provide:}
textBeforeTable: This is somewhat preliminary and subject to change as talks are confirmed or otherwise, but the overall structure should hold: [edit] 4.1 Timetable Previous years in Cambridge we had talks in the day on a Friday, followed by pubbage in the evening and assorted activities on the Saturday. This seemed to work, so we'll follow a similar model this year. Sadly we can't have talk space at MSR on a Saturday. If you're having trouble following things on IRC, the discussion page on the wiki might be a good place to leave comments and questions. Planning will be taking place on IRC as per previous years: #anglohaskell on irc.freenode.net [edit] 4 Programme Another guest house right next to the station is Tenison Towers (01223 363924). There's a fairly inexpensive YHA hostel in Cambridge. [edit] 3.2 Hostels Many of undergraduate colleges offer cheap accommodation over the holidays. Locations near MSR include Churchill College (online booking), Wolfson Court (an annexe of Girton College), Fitzwillian College, Robinson College, New Hall Murray Edwards (female only; recently renamed) and Burwells Field (an annexe of Trinity College). (This map might prove useful.) [edit] 3.1 Nearby Colleges I live in a studio flat
textAfterTable: [edit] 4.2 Talks Volunteers please! Previously we have had a largely more practical set of talks than you might find at Fun in the Afternoon or an academic event. This was a good thing, and some of the best talks were from people who were far from considering themselves as experts, so feel free to tell us about your experiences. In the event that more talks are offered than we have time for at MSR, we'll have to work out what we can do to find more time. Talks planned and/or offered: Neil Mitchell - hopefully "Make Considered Harmful" Tom Schrijvers - "Monadic Constraint Programming" Tristan Allwood - "Using the GHC API to automatically find errors" Neil Brown - "CSP Models on the Cheap" (like several others, I spoke last year -- so others should have priority if we get too many talks) Sam Martin - "Functional languages in games development: plotting the coup" Peter McArthur - Saturday afternoon workshop: "From Map to Monads" Monads for the nervous [edit] 4.2.1 Abstracts People giving talks should add these as they have them :-) Monadic Constraint Programming A constraint programming system combines two essential components: a constraint solver and a search engine.
